channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Evolving Strategy: Strategy Shift for ISIS: Inflicting Terror in Distant Lands
item.description: The recent violence in Paris and Beirut and the downing of a Russian passenger jet appear to be part of a centrally planned campaign of attacks by an evolving Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: The Paris attacks appeared part of a larger campaign by the Islamic State.

item.title: Kurds Investigate Reports of Mass Grave of Yazidis in Sinjar
item.description: A Kurdistan government team plans to excavate the site to try to confirm suspicions of executed older Yazidi women whom the Islamic State did not want as sex slaves.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Kurds in Iraq Face Fast and Erratic Threat in ISIS Suicide Drivers
item.description: Cellphone video recorded by a Kurdish fighter captures a frightening truck bomb explosion near Sinjar, one day before Kurds captured the city.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kurdish fighters ordered a truck to stop Friday in Sinjar, Iraq. The Islamic State is using suicide drivers to attack their positions on a strategic highway.

item.title: Al Aqsa TV Chronicles Palestinian Uprising, Keeping Hamas in Picture
item.description: The Hamas-run channel, broadcasting from Gaza City, covers the distant conflict as a way for Hamas to remain relevant and challenge its rival, Fatah.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID and MAJD AL WAHEIDI
item.media:credit: Loulou d’Aki for The New York Times
item.media:description: Raji al-Hams, right, is the host of “This Is Palestine,” a political program on the Hamas-run Al Aqsa satellite channel in Gaza City.

item.title: 5 Ukrainian Soldiers Killed as Cease-Fire Offenses Rise
item.description: The Ukrainian military said the death toll was its highest since a fragile cease-fire with pro-Russian separatists began two months ago.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: The President: Paris Gunmen Single Out François Hollande, and Leave Him With Few Palatable Responses
item.description: The French president, who was reportedly mentioned by name as attackers stormed a rock concert in Paris, faces a difficult and perilous path forward as he decides how to respond.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: President François Hollande of France in Paris on Saturday. Attackers at a rock concert reportedly mentioned him by name.

item.title: Day After Paris Attacks, Familiar Fear Grips a Wary New York
item.description: The catastrophic events in Paris on Friday put law enforcement agencies on heightened alert, and left people waking up to the weekend in the city coping with a creeping sense of dread.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN MUELLER and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers at the National September 11 Memorial in New York on Saturday.

item.title: France Confronts ‘Absolute Barbarity’
item.description: Parisians who went out on Friday night to listen to music, watch soccer, or enjoy a meal or drink with friends, quickly became engulfed in a blood-soaked drama.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS and MILAN SCHREUER
item.media:description: People lay on the sidewalk outside a cafe on Friday night while others tended to them, after a series of coordinated attacks in and around Paris that left more than 120 people dead.

item.title: Attacker’s Possible Link to Migrant Trail Heightens Security Fears
item.description: French officials revealed that one of the attackers was carrying a Syrian passport, and perhaps may have entered Europe along the migrant trail. Poland moved first to shut the door.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE and RICK LYMAN

item.title: Music Critic, Lawyer and U.S. Student Are Among Victims in Paris Attacks
item.description: The identities of the victims in Paris began to emerge slowly on Saturday, but families continued to struggle to find information about missing loved ones.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ

item.title: As Paris Terror Attacks Unfolded, Social Media Tools Offered Help in Crisis
item.description: Facebook activated its Safety Check tool while Twitter put its new Moments tool to use, highlighting top news tweets about the attacks.
item.dc:creator: VINDU GOEL and SYDNEY EMBER

item.title: Parisians Fear Terror Attacks Will Divide, Not Unite, the City
item.description: Friday’s killings came just 10 months after the massacre at Charlie Hebdo, provoking new concern about France’s ability to manage the deep gulf between Muslims and non-Muslims.
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN
item.media:credit: Pierre Terdjman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Parisians gather around Rue de Charonne near where gunmen opened fire on a restaurant and killed about 18 people.

item.title: Attacks in Paris Add Urgency to Talks on Ending Syria War
item.description: Top diplomats from more than a dozen countries met to discuss how to end the crisis in Syria, vowing to redouble their efforts to confront terrorism.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Israeli Forces Destroy Family Homes of 4 Palestinians Accused in Shootings
item.description: The demolitions on Saturday were the most sweeping use of a recently revived, controversial antiterrorism measure since unrest escalated last month.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Three Teams of Coordinated Attackers Carried Out Assault on Paris, Officials Say; Hollande Blames ISIS
item.description: The assault on Paris was carried out by three teams of attackers — including one who traveled to Europe on a Syrian passport along with the flow of migrants — on behalf of ISIS, officials said.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER, AURELIEN BREEDEN and KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Oscar Pistorius Makes Rare Appearance
item.description: Mr. Pistorius walked into a South African police station on Saturday to report for community service, his first public sighting since he was released from prison last month and moved to house arrest.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: To Save Paris, Defeat ISIS
item.description: The only adequate response to the slaughter in France is military and the objective must be to crush ISIS.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN
item.media:credit: Stephane De Sakutin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President François Hollande of France, right, with Prime Minister Manuel Valls after a security meeting on Saturday.

item.title: A Poet’s Election Victory Over a Former General Speaks of a New Myanmar
item.description: Perhaps no election victory was more eloquent than that of U Tin Thit, a poet and former political prisoner who defeated a former defense minister.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: U Tin Thit, a poet and former political prisoner who defeated a former general in the Myanmar elections, in his home village of Kyi Daung Kan.

item.title: Paris Attacks: What We Know and Don’t Know
item.description: A briefing with the latest information.
item.dc:creator: VICTORIA SHANNON
item.media:description: The French government declared a state of emergency, tightened border controls and mobilized 1,500 soldiers following attacks in Paris on Friday night.

item.title: News Media Scrambles to Cover Paris Shootings
item.description: American media outlets rushed reporters to Paris, while networks shifted their programming in the wake of the killings.
item.dc:creator: JOHN KOBLIN
